summary: The Airey case concerns Mrs. Johanna Airey, an Irish national, who seeks to obtain a judicial separation from her husband due to his physical and mental cruelty towards her and their children. Mrs. Airey has been unable to find a solicitor willing to act for her due to the high costs involved, which she cannot afford. The case relates to the alleged breaches of Articles 6 para. 1, 8, 13, and 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights (Convention) by the Government of Ireland. The Commission's request sought a decision from the Court on whether the facts of the case disclosed a breach by the Government of its obligations under the Convention. The Court held that the State's failure to provide Mrs. Airey with an effective right of access to the High Court due to the prohibitive cost of litigation and the complexity of the procedure was a breach of Article 6 para. 1 of the Convention. The Court also found that Ireland's failure to provide an accessible legal procedure in family-law matters violated Mrs. Airey's right to respect for her private and family life under Article 8 of the Convention.

Reasoning:

The Airey case makes a significant contribution to the development of the Court's case law on Article 6 (right to a fair trial) and Article 8 (right to respect for private and family life) of the European Convention on Human Rights. The case establishes that a State's failure to provide an effective right of access to the courts and an accessible legal procedure in family law matters constitutes a breach of these articles.

The case has been landmark in its impact on the development of the Court's jurisprudence on the accessibility of the law and the right to a fair trial in family law matters. The Court's finding that the high costs of litigation and the complexity of the procedure in the Irish courts made it impossible for Mrs. Airey to exercise her right of access to the courts was a significant departure from existing case law.

The case has also been influential in shaping the Court's approach to Article 8, emphasizing the importance of an accessible legal procedure in family law matters as part of the right to respect for private and family life. The judgment has been cited and relied upon in numerous subsequent cases, including cases concerning the right to a fair trial and the accessibility of the law.

Overall, the Airey case is considered High in importance because it has made a significant contribution to the development of the Court's case law, clarified the obligations of States under Articles 6 and 8, and has had a lasting impact on the jurisprudence of the Court.
